awd_titl_txt: Evidence-Based Science Policy Workshop; Washington, D.C., January 8-9, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides a forum for the presentation and discussion of NSF's Science of Science and Innovation Policy (SciSIP)Science Policy Research Reports.  The principal investigators of each of the seventeen reports will be invited to present a report that provides evidence-based recommendations for policy and practice.
 
The workshop will be organized around seven major themes: (1) improving communication to facilitate more informed decision making;(2) improving data for decision makers;(3) investigation of tools to support innovation, such as inducement prizes; (4) benefits of interdisciplinary and collaborative research efforts; (5) benefits of research portfolios versus large projects; (6) impacts of inclusivity and immigration on the science labor force; and (7) opportunities for entrepreneurism. Members of STEP's Innovation Policy Forum will serve as moderators.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Through grants, contracts, and loans, the federal government invests over $140 billion annually in research and development (R&D). Because there is more research than can be funded with this budget, the government must decide how it will allocate scarce scientific resources to maximize societal benefits. Congress allocates funding during the annual budget process, generally down to the level of specific offices or programs. These offices and programs generally receive more applications for funding than their budgets can fund, and often have little information on how to make funding decisions or how other federal, state, or local policies may interact with these decisions.

The Board on Science, Technology, and Economic Policy (STEP) of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine convened a workshop in Washington, DC, on 8-9 January 2018 to convey the findings from projects, funded under the National Science Foundation’s Science Policy Research Reports program, that investigated policy issues relating to government decision making and the allocation of scarce scientific resources. The primary investigators of the reports that resulted from the projects were invited to present their work. The presented research and authors included (presenters marked with and asterisk):

“A Research Agenda for Science of Broadening Participation: STEM Employment of Individuals with Disabilities” --- Kaye Husbands Fealing, Georgia Institute of Technology*, Paul Manuel Aviles Baker, Georgia Institute of Technology*, Connie L. McNeely, George Mason University*, and Andrew Hanus, Georgia Institute of Technology

“Student Visa Policy and the Scientific Workforce” --- Sarah Turner, University of Virginia*

“Efforts to Improve Non-Academic Career Outcomes among University Postdocs” --- Marla Parker, California State University-Los Angeles*, and Christopher Hayter, Arizona State University

“Infrastructure for Interdisciplinarity” --- Erin Leahey, University of Arizona*

“Funding Team Science” --- Jonathon Cummings, Duke University*

“Groundwater Security Under Drought: Synthesis and Analysis of Information, and Recommendations to Address Knowledge Gaps” --- Amanda Fencl, University of California-Davis*, Ruth Langridge, University of California-Santa Cruz, and Linda Esteli Barrientos, University of California-Davis

“Regulation, Deregulation, and Technological Innovation” --- David Hart, George Mason University*

“The Use of Innovation Prizes in Government” --- Luciano Kay, University of California-Santa Barbara*

“Manufacturing Location & Technology Changes: Implications for Innovation and the Nature of Work” --- Kate Whitefoot*, Christophe Combemale, and Erica Fuchs, Carnegie Mellon University

“The Effects of Patents on Innovation, Diffusion, and Access” --- Bhaven Sampat, Columbia University*

“Advising the President on Science Policy and the Role of the President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology” --- Kenneth M. Evans and Kirstin R.W. Matthews, Rice University*

“New Directions for Impact” --- J. Britt Holbrook, New Jersey Institute of Technology*, and Robert Frodeman, University of North Texas

“Facilitating the Use of Evidence in Science Policy Making” --- Kimberley Isett, Georgia Institute of Technology*, and Diana Hicks, Georgia Institute of Technology*

“Government Brokerage of Innovation Networks” --- Andrew Schrank, Brown University*, and Joshua Whitford, Columbia University*

“Employee Non-compete Agreements” --- Matthew Marx, Boston University*

“Institutional Innovation to Close the Infrastructure Knowledge-Action Gap” --- Christine Kirchhoff, University of Connecticut*, John Katzenberger, Aspen Global Change Institute*, and James Arnott, Aspen Global Change Institute and University of Michigan*

“The Use of Research Portfolios in Science Policy” --- Nicholas Vonortas, George Washington University*, and Ismael Rafols, Valencia Polytechnic University and Sussex University*

The workshop expanded the literature on how to measure impacts of federal investments in research and how to communicate the gains from those federal investments to policymakers. It explored the opportunities for using new tools to measure impact and the potential and challenges that policymakers face in understanding technical research and data, and it enhanced understanding of how federal grants, contracts, and other government tools to support research and development complement private-sector investment.  The workshop organized these papers around five basic themes: expanding the scientific labor force, including disabled veterans; interdisciplinary approaches to improve decision making; innovation, including innovative approaches to funding such as inducement prizes; techniques to improve government decision making such as using alternative metrics of impact or assessing impact based on research portfolios; and expanding the impacts by expanding entrepreneurial outcomes.

The workshop helps NSF and other federal agencies improve the processes under which they make and monitor research and innovation awards, including how to evaluate optimal grant size, how to become more efficient at selecting projects, and how to evaluate multidisciplinary research and development. The workshop enhanced the information that is available to researchers and federal agency experts to identify what data are needed to bridge the gap between science and decision making. In turn, this information enables NSF and other research agencies to improve their own assessments and management practices. It also enables them to better communicate to policy makers and to the public the impact of investments in scientific research.

The workshop agenda, presentations, and the presenters' final papers are available on the website of the National Academies' STEP Board.
